title: Run full-text search SQL on a Mastodon federated stream

last_post.content:
A few people have asked me if there is an easy way to run full-text search on the "firehose" of Mastodon.

Here is a gist where I've open-sourced a very simple implementation for loading the real-time federated stream into a full-text search table you can then query using SQL: https://gist.github.com/ummjackson/050044e661c6c5fa3ae61aa8a8baf485

It's hacky but it works, hope someone finds it useful.

⚛️ react-resizable-panels 0.0.23 just released:

https://github.com/bvaughn/react-resizable-panels/releases/tag/v0.0.23

I think it's probably ready for v1.0, but I'll give it a couple more days first to see.

title: [FEATURE REQUEST] Turn off comments · Discussion #21444 · mastodon/mastodon

last_post.content:
Some folks might ask, "Why not wait till Mastodon adds that feature?"

Because I don't want to wait.

I want it now.

I've already added this as a Feature request in Mastodon's Github months ago:

https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/discussions/21444

The great thing about the Fediverse is that I don't have to wait on Mastodon to give me what I need.

That's because alternatives to Mastodon exist on the Fediverse.

The masto frontend is written in React, which is linked to the rails underneath with redux, and i don't totally understand that yet. The React components are sort of odd, and have both imperative and declarative parts to them, but when expanded a thread is a single Status component that represents the focused status with a DetailedStatus and the ancestors and descendants with arrays of StatusContainers.

So to make a treelike representation we would need to probably make the component recursive, where each status contains its own children, rather than a single top-level component with a single layer of children.

The masto frontend is written in React, which is linked to the rails underneath with redux, and i don't totally understand that yet. The React components are sort of odd, and have both imperative and declarative parts to them, but when expanded a thread is a single Status component that represents the focused status with a DetailedStatus and the ancestors and descendants with arrays of StatusContainers.

So to make a treelike representation we would need to probably make the component recursive, where each status contains its own children, rather than a single top-level component with a single layer of children.

The masto frontend is written in React, which is linked to the rails underneath with redux, and i don't totally understand that yet. The React components are sort of odd, and have both imperative and declarative parts to them, but when expanded a thread is a single Status component that represents the focused status with a DetailedStatus and the ancestors and descendants with arrays of StatusContainers.

So to make a treelike representation we would need to probably make the component recursive, where each status contains its own children, rather than a single top-level component with a single layer of children.

Problem: Fedi posts have a treelike structure to them, where each post can have a single post it is in reply to ( in_reply_to_id ) but many posts that reply to it. However the interface just represents them as a flat list, which makes them hard to navigate and read - it's hard to know if a given status is replying to the OP or to the post above it. This gets really really hard when threads get deeper and broader.

Posts (statuses in the code) already have the notion of a "thread" but in the ruby the tree is collapsed to a list in the descendents method, which does a treelike SQL query and then sorts the results, bringing self-replies to the top.

Problem: Fedi posts have a treelike structure to them, where each post can have a single post it is in reply to ( in_reply_to_id ) but many posts that reply to it. However the interface just represents them as a flat list, which makes them hard to navigate and read - it's hard to know if a given status is replying to the OP or to the post above it. This gets really really hard when threads get deeper and broader.

Posts (statuses in the code) already have the notion of a "thread" but in the ruby the tree is collapsed to a list in the descendents method, which does a treelike SQL query and then sorts the results, bringing self-replies to the top.

Finally added a #Hometown feature I have wanted for a long time. Media in a timeline that lacks alt text now has a little warning icon in the lower left (shown here with mouseover text).

title: GitHub - kdpsingh/TidyTable.jl: Julia package that wraps the R tidytable package (tidyverse syntax with the speed of data.table)

last_post.content:
Introducing TidyTable.jl, a ridiculous #JuliaLang 📦 that brings the syntax of #RStats tidyverse and the speed of data.table to Julia by wrapping the tidytable R package.

Obviously, Julia and the DataFrames package is plenty fast to begin with. This package isn’t about beating it on benchmarks since it requires data transfer to R.

But if you’re an R user dipping your toes in Julia, this package allows you to literally write R code, which is kind of cool.

GitHub: https://github.com/kdpsingh/TidyTable.jl

OK Here's a basic implementation of #FetchAllReplies :
https://github.com/NeuromatchAcademy/mastodon/tree/feature-fetch-replies

Button at the bottom of a thread that lets you load more replies. It queries the context endpoint of the host server to get a list of replies, and then since I noticed that merely searching for a post will add it to the database, I just did that here and searched for all the posts.

Need to find a more direct way to add posts directly without having to ping all the involved servers, and also currently you need to do a refresh after clicking the button rather than the new posts being added dynamically, but anyway it's a first draft.

#MastoDev #HackThePlanet

Compiling my yearly top-papers list and "MaxViT: Multi-axis Vision Transformer" should probably make the cut.

MaxViT is a vision transformer with local-global interaction between visual tokens within a single block.

The so-called multi-axis attention scales linearly (vs quadratic complexity in the original ViT).

You can use it for
- classification
- object detection
- instance segmentation

and generative modeling.

Paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2204.01697

Code: https://github.com/google-research/maxvit

Sport trivia: the most common surname among Finnish men's national ice hockey team players in all times (as far as Wikipedia knows anyway) is Kapanen. @touqo@twitter.com threw the question/hypothesis, and I decided to investigate
https://github.com/tts/Varia/blob/main/hockeyplayers.R #rstats

"Juno: a Python-based graphical package for optical system design" — A complete library that includes a graphical user interface to design and visualise arbitrary optical elements, set up wave propagation simulations and visualise their results.

Paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.12540
Code: https://github.com/DeMarcoLab/juno

#NewPaper #Python #Simulation

<<Find this useful? Please boost so that others can benefit too 🙂>>

Scikit-learn 1.2 is out: https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/releases/tag/1.2.0

Was an eventful December & I totally missed the new release of my favorite #machinelearning library!

My personal highlights are around the HistGradientBoostingClassifier (if you haven't used it yet, it's a LightGBM impl that works really well)

It now supports

1. interaction constraints (in trees, features that appear along a particular path are considered as "interacting")
2. class weights
3. feature names for categorical features

title: Experimental feature gate proposal `interoperable_abi` by joshtriplett · Pull Request #105586 · rust-lang/rust

last_post.content:
The experimental Rust PR to add a more expressive "interop" ABI on top of the C ABI is IMHO the most exciting new effort that happened in Rust in the last few years.

Thanks to @josh and others for starting this very important work 🥳​

https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/105586

Also @Mara's reply seems to indicate that some serious thought is now also put into other related areas, especially for handling Rust dynamic libraries.

https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/105586#issuecomment-1349332850

Very exciting stuff for making Rust a better choice in various areas where exactly these topics were slowing down or hindering adoption.

#Rust #RustLang

title: GitHub - lucahammer/fediporter: Notes on importing content to Mastodon.

last_post.content:
Over the last few days, I experimented with moving my Twitter archive to my personal #Mastodon account @luca@social.luca.run and finally succeeded.

I had to modify the Mastodon source to allow backdated posts and prevent it from spamming other instances with old posts. Because image descriptions aren't included in the Twitter export, I had to request them from the API. There I got full text for truncated Retweets as well.

Incomplete notes:
https://github.com/lucahammer/fediporter

#TwitterMigration #MastoAdmin

New #preprint - Department-level comparison of universities' scientific output: A bibliometric study of Greek universities 🇬🇷 :

:oa: https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.12032

After collecting the #Scopus IDs were calculated statistical metrics by exploiting the Scopus #API and creating scripts in :rstats: using the #bibliometrix package to retrieve the data and generate statistics. The created scripts have been published on GitHub in the form of R functions: https://github.com/gnk02/bibliostats/

#university #bibliometrics

title: GitHub - MichelNivard/GPTstudio: GPT addins for Rstudio

last_post.content: Progress on a GPT addin for #Rstudio and #rstats. It now does spelling/grammar, adds comments to code, and writes code or text from a prompt. If none of those are precisely what you want, it also has a freeform GPT editor in a shiny app. (used here to translate poetry from French to English but can do code things as well obviously) find the alpha version of the app here: https://github.com/MichelNivard/GPTstudio

Can we see a list of #Mastodon accounts we follow and the list(s) we've added each to?

@judell answered this with the open source Steampipe platform and SQL: https://blog.jonudell.net/2022/12/22/lists-and-people-on-mastodon/

It's also possible with R and the {rtoot} 📦 . Code is in this GitHub gist if anyone else is interested:

https://gist.github.com/smach/1570d42abb30da72ea8993c89c76c882

You need the dev version of rtoot and to authenticate with a user token for your own account.

#rstats #rtoot #SteamPipe #SQL

title: GitHub - rust-ndarray/ndarray: ndarray: an N-dimensional array with array views, multidimensional slicing, and efficient operations

last_post.content:
https://github.com/rust-ndarray/ndarray

This is really cool. I need to try it in combination with https://github.com/arkworks-rs libs - so far the common practice for defining multidimensional arrays are nested vecs, which is not the best for memory access (all vecs allocated separately on the heap).

title: GitHub - aconchillo/homebrew-guile: A Homebrew Tap for Guile libraries and applications.

last_post.content:
And now that Fibers 1.2.0 supports macOS, you can finally do:

brew install fibers

But not only that! Guile Goblins is now also available:

brew install guile-goblins

Those are "almost" all my Holidays' gifts! Happy Hacking!

#guile #scheme

https://github.com/aconchillo/homebrew-guile

I've released version 2.0.0 of my RSS to ActivityPub converter! This now provides functionality I'd hacked in to https://rss.friend.camp - it requires OAuth 2.0 authorization for someone to create a new AP account for an RSS feed.

I used to run this service "in the open" but was overwhelmed by spammers. Now the admin of a Mastodon (or Pleroma or any federated server that is an OAuth 2 provider) can provide this converter as a service solely to members of their instance.

https://github.com/dariusk/rss-to-activitypub/releases/tag/v2.0.0

title: Who voted in the PSF Board Elections

last_post.content:
Ever wondered about the development in the board elections of @ThePSF over the past years?

Did you know that there are 3 types of PSF members who can vote? Fellows, Contributing or Managing, and Supporting?

The PSF Diversity & Inclusion group is preparing a really cool event where you can ask anything about all these things.

We will announce it soon, so stay tuned!

In the meantime dive into this interactive chart on @observablehq

https://observablehq.com/@terezaif/who-voted-in-the-psf-board-elections

#thepsf #python #boardelections

:python:📦 New #dataset of #PythonPackaging data right before Christmas! This one has data on over 400K #Python packages and 180K maintainers of those packages.

👉 https://github.com/sethmlarson/pypi-data/releases/tag/2022.12.23

If you've never seen this project, it's a snapshot in time for most packages on #PyPI with data about the package, maintainers, dependencies, URLs, #OpenSSF scorecard data, and more! You can query it via #Datasette or #SQLite.

Check it out here: https://github.com/sethmlarson/pypi-data
